# Film App

## Backend on Express.js

[![N|Solid](data:image/png;base64,)](https://nodesource.com/products/nsolid)


## Front End React.js With Redux
[![N|Solid](data:image/png;base64,)]

[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/joemccann/dillinger.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/joemccann/dillinger)
Hi,
Film App is made on Node's Express.js framework and React.js for redux is used serving APIs and mysql database is used,


## Setting up
  Bellow should installed on system
-  Node.js >=16 Link https://nodejs.org/en/download/ 
-  React >=16.8.0 Link https://reactjs.org/docs/getting-started.html
-  Docker Link https://docs.docker.com/compose/install/


> The Films app
> formatting syntax is to make it as readable
> as possible. The idea is that a
> Markdown-formatted document should be
> publishable as-is, as plain text, without
> looking like it's been marked up with tags
> or formatting instructions.

This text you see here is *actually- written in Markdown! To get a feel
for Markdown's syntax, type some text into the left window and
watch the results in the right.

## Tech

Film app uses a number of open source projects to work properly:

- [ReactJs] - HTML enhanced for web apps!
- [React Bootstrap] - great UI boilerplate for modern web apps
- [node.js] - evented I/O for the backend
- [Express] - fast node.js network app framework [@tjholowaychuk]


## Installation

 requires [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) v16+ to run.

Install the dependencies and devDependencies and start the server.

```sh
cd backend
npm i
npm start
```

For production environments...

```sh
npm install --production
NODE_ENV=production node app
```
```sh
cd frontend
npm i
npm start
```
# If installation is failing due to some issues (TODO some libraries should remove)
```sh
cd frontend
npm i --legacy-peer-deps
npm start
```
## Migrations
running migrations
```sh
cd backend
npm run migrate
```

## Seeding
running Seeds
```sh
cd backend
npm run seed
 #for removing seed
npm run seed:undo
```

## using Docker

Very easy to install and deploy in a Docker container.

By default, the Docker will expose port 8080 for Backend and 3000 for frontend, so change this within the
Dockerfile if necessary. 
build the images.

```sh

docker compose up -d
```

This will create the images for Backend, Frontend and Mysql Database and pull in the necessary dependencies.
Once done, run the Docker image and map the port to whatever you wish on
your host. In this example, we simply map port 8000 of the host to
port 8080 of the Docker (or whatever port was exposed in the Dockerfile):
OR
# you can run only database on Docker and everything else on Os
```sh

docker compose up -d db
```
Verify the deployment by navigating to your server address in
your preferred browser.

Backend:

```sh
127.0.0.1:8080
```
Frontend:

```sh
127.0.0.1:3000
```
## 
## Without Docker
 
After dependencies are installed. change the Environment variables to run without docker
